learning_outcomes.description: Explain how debates about ‘problems’ give rise to discussion of policy responses.
Analyse how policy decisions are made in relation to complex or controversial problems.
Map the influence of various actors/stakeholders in the shaping of problems and policies.
Write a professional research-based report on a policy issue drawing upon relevant policy literature.

assessments.assessment_title: Conceptual Review A and B (1000 words + 20 references)
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 1 consists of two short writing tasks:

  • Conceptual Review A (500 words + 10 references) due 20/3/2026 5.00pm.

Conceptual Review A is valued at 10%.

  • Conceptual Review B (500 words + 10 references) due 17/4/2026 5.00pm.

Conceptual Review B is valued at 10%. Combined, Conceptual Review A and B are valued at 20%.

About this assessment:

Conceptual Review A and B

For Conceptual Review A, students should write an answer to one question which is based on material covered in Week 1,2, 3 and 4. Similar, for Conceptual Review B, students should also write an answer to one question which is based on material covered in Week 5, 6, 7 and 8. To answer the questions for Conceptual Review A and B, students are required to use the theories, concepts and models that have been covered in Week 2.

For both Conceptual Review A and B, students will be provided a list of questions developed based on the relevant weekly topics they can choose from. These questions will be posted on Blackboard Ultra at the beginning of the semester.

Answers are required to be 500 words (excluding in-text references and reference list) with a +-10% tolerance allowed.

Students must relate their answers to the policy literature discussed in the course as outlined further above. Students should not simply give their opinions or use internet summaries. Please note, the use of any Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) is forbidden and will constitute student misconduct.

Students' answer should include 10 relevant references per Conceptual Review. For advice on referencing style, please see the POLSIS Essay Guide. 

ACADEMIC INTEGRITY - IMPORTANT!

Turnitin software to detect plagiarism is automatically employed in the submission process to help examiners assess the originality of all written material. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic, and complex. While students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of this assessment will require critical engagement with specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.assessment_title: Policy Case Study Report (3000 words + references)
assessments.task_description:
Assessment 2 consists of a shorter writing hurdle and a longer writing task:

  • Proposal for Policy Case Study Report (including suggestions of references) due 24/4/2026 5.00pm. Discussion of Proposal with Course Convener must happen no later than 17/4/2026.

Proposal for Policy Case Study Report is examined as a Pass/Fail. Students must Pass this hurdle to be eligible to submit their Policy Case Study Report.

  • Policy Case Study Report (3000 words + references) due 8/5/2026 5.00pm.

The Policy Case Study Report is valued at 40%.

About this assessment:

Proposal for Policy Case Study Report

For the Proposal and Policy Case Study Report, a list of suitable research topics will be provided on Blackboard Ultra early in the semester. Students however may negotiate a variation of these to suit their interest.

As a part of this assessment, it is a requirement students discuss their selected topic with the Course Convener. This can be done either in-person before and/or after the seminar or in writing via the Course Convener's UQ staff e-mail (a.jedzini@uq.edu.au). Additionally, it is a requirement students seek approval for working on an agreed topic by submitting their Proposal for the Policy Case Study Report via Turnitin. Passing the Proposal for the Policy Case Study Report is a pre-condition for submitting the Policy Case Study Report.

The Proposal for the Policy Case Study Report will cover the scope including the wording of the topic, the relevant policy theories, the relevant empirical sources for the research, and the student's research approach.

Policy Case Study Report

Students' Policy Case Study Report will analyse a selected policy problem, decision or trend, by relating it to wider theories and issues about the policymaking process as discussed extensively in the course.

The Policy Case Study Report should aim to connect policy theory to the policy example students have chosen. In selecting a policy issue or policy problem or policy process, students need to ensure that their topic is not only of interest to themselves, but is also likely to have a sufficient range of material available for students to provide an in-depth analysis of the actors, processes and context in which the policy decision or policy outcome was produced.

The analytical task is to explain what happened and why in relation to students' policy example.

Where practicable, students might consider using both primary sources (e.g. government documents) and secondary sources (e.g. commentaries by scholars, stakeholders and media analysts). The conceptual task is to connect students' analysis of their problem or policy case to the broader themes and theories discussed in the course.

Simply describing what happened is not enough. Please note, the use of any Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) is forbidden and will constitute student misconduct.

The Policy Case Study Report should be clearly structured and properly referenced (approximately 10 references per 1,000 words) using the POLSIS Essay Guide. The word limit is 3000 words (excluding in-text references, reference list and appendix) with a +-10% tolerance.

If relevant, it is acceptable to attach a short documentary or statistical appendix to back up an argument. This will not itself be the subject to assessment.

ACADEMIC INTEGRITY - IMPORTANT!

Turnitin software to detect plagiarism is automatically employed in the submission process to help examiners assess the originality of all written material. 

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic, and complex. While students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of this assessment will require critical engagement with specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment 3 consists of writing a Policy Brief:

Written Exam (due during end of Semester Exam period 6/06-20/06 2026). The Written Exam date (Online - External Students) will be released by UQ Central closer to the exam period. UQ Central will additionally release the details of undertaking an invigilated written exam online around this time too. Students who are able to sit the Written Exam (Invigilated) in-person is strongly encouraged to do so, however a Written Exam online is held for those students who are unable to attend the written exam in-person.

The Online Written Exam is valued at 30%. Students should note the Online Written Exam lasts 2-hours, is invigilated via Zoom.

About this assessment:

Policy Brief A and B

For the Written Exam, students are required to write two Policy Briefs. These are known as Policy Brief A and Policy Brief B.

Both Policy Briefs are on a particular topic targeted a particular audience. Students are provided a list with topics and corresponding audiences to choose from at the written exam. Policy Brief A will address topics that have been covered in Week 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7, and Policy Brief B will address topics that have been covered in Week 8, 9, 12, 13 and 14.

Students' Policy Brief A and B must be structured like a real-life policy brief. An example of this will be provided on Blackboard Ultra and will also be workshopped in the seminar. Students' structure should include executive summary, aims, critical analysis, recommendations and conclusion. Policy Brief A and B must also use an evidenced-based approach to policy advice by relating it to theories, concepts, models and empirical research about policymaking as covered in the course.

Students' Policy Brief A and B should be clearly structured with title, headings, and so forth. Given this is a closed book exam, students are not expected to incorporate and cite sources covered in the course. There is a also no set word limit as the exam is paper based.

learning_activities.topic:
Introduction, Course Overview and Key Themes

This is the first week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to the course outline, content including the central ideas of public policy and requirements of assessments. More specifically, the lecture will provide an introduction to key topics such as how to define and conceptualise public policy, how public policy is conducted across liberal democracies, who gets to influence and participate in public policymaking and how, why particular public policy decisions are made and how, and the extent to which different public policy instruments lead to certain public policy outcomes. In this week's seminar, students will be introduced to each other for the first time, have the opportunity to learn more and ask questions about the course outline and content, and upcoming assessments. Finally, students will also be doing small-group discussions and activities on the topics covered in the pre-recorded lecture.

Learning outcomes: L01

learning_activities.topic:
Theories and Models for Understanding Public Policy

This is the second week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to the relevant theories, concepts and models of public policy. More specifically, the lecture will provide an overview of how public policy is theorised and conceptualised in the academic literature, and how different theories and concepts help making sense of public policy issues and decisions. The lecture will also cover the boundaries including limitations of public policy theories and concepts, and what the empirical implications of these are for understanding public policy in practise. In this week's seminar, students will have the opportunity to engage in discussions and activities that address these topics in the pre-recorded lecture.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Tackling Complex and Wicked Problems

This is the third week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to how complex and wicked problems are defined and conceptualised, and how they can be distinguished from other public policy issues. More specifically, the lecture will provide an overview of what complex and wicked problems are, how they can be identified, and how they can be understood. The lecture will also cover what factors that generate complex and wicked problems and what the solutions to these might be. The lecture will additionally cover what the real-life implications of complex and wicked problems are for public policymakers and other policy decision-makers, and what strategies they might choose to confront and address such problems. In this week's seminar, students will have the opportunity to engage in discussions and activities that address these topics in the pre-recorded lecture. Students will also be workshopping Assessment 1, Conceptual Review A, in groups.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02

learning_activities.topic:
Agenda-Setting, Media and Issue Framing

This is the fourth week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to how public policy issues are identified and framed to influence the policy agenda. More specifically, the lecture will provide an overview of what policy agenda-setting is and who has the capacity and/or resources to set the policy agenda, the importance of agenda-setting to the public policymaking process, how agenda-setting informs what public policy issues are selected or not, how public policy issues help illuminating bigger underlying wicked problems, and the way in which public policy issues potentially offer feasible and legitimate solutions to address these wicked problems. In this week's seminar, students will have the opportunity to engage in discussions and activities that address these topics in the pre-recorded lecture. Students will also be able to ask any questions about Assessment 1, Conceptual Review A, which is due this week.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Participation, Consultation and Stakeholder Engagement

This is the fifth week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to the aims and broader rationales for including every-day citizens, communities and stakeholders in the making of the policy decisions that affect them. More specifically, the lecture will provide an overview of the historical origins of participation and engagement in democratic governance, different models for engaging citizens, communities and stakeholders in policymaking, the strengths and short-comings of community engagement, and how to empower policymakers with the appropriate knowledge and tools to identify the most suitable methods of community engagement. In this week's seminar, students will have the opportunity to engage in discussions and activities that address these topics in the pre-recorded lecture.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
Selection and Application of Policy Instruments

This is the sixth week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to what policy instruments are and how they are applied in practice. More specifically, the lecture will provide an overview of the relationship between policy goals and policy instruments, the different types of policy instruments available to policymakers, the ways in which policy instruments are central to policy design, and the importance of conditions for policy instruments to be effective. The lecture will also cover the relevance of historical context in the development and implementation of policy instruments. In this week's seminar, students will have the opportunity to engage in discussions and activities that address these topics in the pre-recorded lecture. Students will also be workshopping, Assessment 2, Proposal for Case Study Report including Case Study Report, in groups.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

Policy Implementation and Coordination

This is the seventh week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to what public policy implementation and coordination is, and how it relates to public services and the delivery of these. More specifically, the lecture will provide an overview of how public policy implementation is different from the making of policy, different models of public policy implementation, what is considered successful and unsuccessful public policy implementation, and what conditions that are necessary for public policy implementation to be effective. In this week's seminar, students will have the opportunity to engage in discussions and activities that address these topics in the pre-recorded lecture. Students will also be workshopping, Assessment 2, Proposal for Case Study Report including Case Study Report, in groups.

learning_activities.topic:
Policy Success and Failure

This is the eight week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to how to identify and understand policy success in liberal democracies, and the importance of evaluating policies in this context. More specifically, the lecture will provide an overview of the aims of evaluating policies, the theoretical and conceptual frameworks for evaluating policies, what aspects of policies that can or cannot be evaluated, and the criteria for determining what is considered policy success and failures. In this week's seminar, students will have the opportunity to engage in discussions and activities that address these topics in the pre-recorded lecture. Students will also have the opportunity to ask any questions about Assessment 2, Proposal for Case Study Report, which is due this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Policy Transfer and Adaptation

This is the ninth week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to how public policies can be transferred and adopted across different political and institutional contexts. More specifically, the lecture will provide an overview of where public policy ideas come from, the boundaries of and the extent to which public policies can transfer through time and place, why some public policies are more popular to transfer than others, and the real-life implications for those who are impacted by public policy transfers. In this week's seminar, students will have the opportunity to engage in discussions and activities that address these topics in the pre-recorded lecture. Students will also have the opportunity to ask any questions about Assessment 2, Proposal for Case Study Report, which is due next week.

Evidence-Based Policymaking

This is the eleventh week of the course. In this week's pre-recorded lecture, students will be introduced to what the role of evidence-based policymaking is in today's public policy landscape, and how evidence-based policymaking can improve policy decision-making and public policy outcomes. More specifically, the lecture will provide an overview of what evidence-based policy making is and how the concept originated, what the empirical and practical lessons of evidence-based policymaking are, what types of knowledge and/or expertise that is considered evidence-based (and therefore valuable), and the extent to which evidence-based policymaking aligns with what works in practice. In this week's seminar, students will have the opportunity to engage in discussions and activities that address these topics in the pre-recorded lecture.
